Dear All,

I am using knox Token and it works. I can get Token when I login and other apis do not work without Token. That is OKAY.
But I need to know user of the related token to check whether s/he will be authenticated to do that?

I have seen several questions same with me. But all of them is closed without any answer. 

Any help will be appreciated.

Thanks.

items.title: Get Login Data Before Validation
items.body:
I've been looking at the LoginView class to get an idea on the method to override in order to get the user's username field and password submitted before passing it to Knox for validation. The reason being that, the username field value will be passed to me in base64, I need to decode it before passing it on to Knox for validation and do the needful. 

What method can I override to get the login data? any idea on how to go about this?

items.title: Configure expiry serilializer
items.body:
With the new release `4.0.x` we now return the `expiry` date which is great, but it cannot be formatted the way I want it to be without overloading the [post](https://github.com/James1345/django-rest-knox/blob/master/knox/views.py#L30) method of `LoginView`.

I would like to be able to return the `expiry` directly as a Unix Timestamp instead.
An easy way to achieve this goal could be to add a configurable expiry serializer, we could then import from `knox_settings`. (basically in the same fashion it has been done for `UserSerializer`.

I would be willing to provide such a patch if you guys agree with the idea.

items.title: Object of type 'AuthToken' is not JSON serializable
items.body:
I'm getting the above error when creating token, here's the code:

`
from rest_framework import generics, permissions
from rest_framework.response import Response
from knox.models import AuthToken
from .serializers import UserSerializer, RegisterSerializer

class RegisterAPI(generics.GenericAPIView):
    serializer_class = RegisterSerializer

    def post(self, request, *args, **kwargs):
        serializer = self.get_serializer(data=request.data)
        serializer.is_valid(raise_exception=True)
        user = serializer.save()
        return Response({
            "user": UserSerializer(user, context=self.get_serializer_context()).data,
            "token": AuthToken.objects.create(user)
        })
 `

what am I doing wrong here

items.title: Fully customisable LoginView response
items.body:
Currently, you require a user to override the post method in the event we need to change the format of the full response from LoginView. 

I suggest instead taking a parameter for the full response serializer `KNOX_LOGIN_RESPONSE_SERIALIZER`, with a method for us to override to provide context, with the token included. `def get_response_context(self, token)`

items.title: Why are there two non-auth exit strategies?
items.body:
In the [authenticate method](https://github.com/James1345/django-rest-knox/blob/master/knox/auth.py#L41) there are two potential exits: returning `None` or raising an exception:

- https://github.com/James1345/django-rest-knox/blob/master/knox/auth.py#L46
- https://github.com/James1345/django-rest-knox/blob/master/knox/auth.py#L49
- https://github.com/James1345/django-rest-knox/blob/master/knox/auth.py#L53
- https://github.com/James1345/django-rest-knox/blob/master/knox/auth.py#L56

When returning `None`, an API class that looks like this:

```python
class LogInView(GenericAPIView):
  authentication_classes = (TokenAuthentication,)
  permission_classes = (AllowAny,)
    
  def post(self, request, *args, **kwargs):
    pass # do something
```

works, but when raising an exception, the `get`  method never gets executed. This means that a custom `LogIn` class cannot authenticate a user if for some reason the user ended up with a broken Token as it would be [on line 49](https://github.com/James1345/django-rest-knox/blob/master/knox/auth.py#L49).

I made a personal copy of Knox to make some other changes, but one of the changes I did was to standardize on always returning None. It seems to work just fine in marking the request as not authenticated and thus classes defined like this:

```python
class ChangePasswordView(APIView):
  authentication_classes = (TokenAuthentication,)
  permission_classes = (IsAuthenticated,)
    
  def post(self, request, *args, **kwargs):
    pass # do something
```

work as expected in the requirement of authentication.

I intend to make a PR request with my improvements to Knox, but I would need to clarify whether this behavior is intended or a bug, to see how I turn my own version of Knox into a contribution to this one.

items.title: Carify Token process is JWT or not?
items.body:
In the documentation you speak about tokens, and that they should not be stored within a database. 

The usage of tokens in memory is a basically JWT Token, as explained here: 

* https://jwt.io/introduction/ (Foundation)
* https://medium.com/@apcelent/json-web-token-tutorial-with-example-in-python-df7dda73b579 (Example)

Is this what you implemented, and made available as a Django Package? I like your general setup, and like to clarify it before we start using it.

Is it simply a matter of extending AuthToken with custom fields, extending TokenAuthenticator with MyAuthToken as model and then using MyTokenAuthenticator in settings.py.

I am not sure if this is related to #159.

Im testing out this library and so far I am really liking it, but I wonder if there is a way to throttle or limit the amount of keys a user can have?

I am willing to take a stab at this if it does not exist, but im curious to hear what everyone else thinks about it?

Kindly,

items.title: Views do not have a serializer_class
items.body:
I am attempting to use django-rest-swagger for API documentation with DRF 3.8.1. Loading fails with the following exception:

```
'LoginView' should either include a `serializer_class` attribute, or override the `get_serializer_class()` method.
```

In the DRF documentation, it specifies that:
> `serializer_class` - [...] Typically, you must either set this attribute, or override the get_serializer_class() method.

http://www.django-rest-framework.org/api-guide/generic-views/#attributes

If I'm understanding the documentation correctly, it appears that DRF `GenericAPIView` must have a `serializer_class`, which `LoginView`, `LogoutView`, and `LogoutAllView` do not, so I believe this is a bug in django-rest-knox and not in django-rest-swagger. 

I'm going to override the classes in my project to add a `serializer_class`, but I think it might be a fairly involved set of changes. If you're interested in a pull request, please let me know and I can work on creating one once I make the changes.

items.title: Why does LoginView have  permission_classes = (IsAuthenticated,)
items.body:
Hi,
I currently use djoser library to do the equivalent but want to be able to support multiple tokens per user which rest-knox supports. But I am unable to get it to work.

I am trying to get rest-knox to work but running into an HTTP 401 issue that I think others have reported. However I dont understand why you have LoginView have    permission_classes = (IsAuthenticated,) Shouldnt this be changed AllowedAny.

Why should you have some other type of login first and then call the rest-knox login to login again?
If you look into the login view of djoser, that also has AllowAny permission for the login view.

Thanks

items.title: Need more information in setup knox docs
items.body:
In the [docs (Installation > Setup)](https://james1345.github.io/django-rest-knox/installation/#setup-knox), it says to "Make knox's TokenAuthentication your default authentification class for django-rest-framework." 

[Only way later in the docs](https://james1345.github.io/django-rest-knox/auth/) does it mention that doing so will require you to override the login view. 

It took me forever to figure out how I was getting a 401 even though I followed all the setup instructions. I think the information about overriding should be included in the setup, or there should be different setup instructions altogether so people can run a test quickly and make sure everything works post-install.

items.title: After authenticating one user, everyone has access event without providing a token
items.body:
Hello!

We are currently testing django-rest-knox and are having some strange behaviors:

Login with dummy view:

@api_view()
```
def login_request(request):
    user, created = User.objects.get_or_create(username__iexact='hansblub')
    new_token = AuthToken.objects.create(user)
    return Response({"TOKEN": new_token})
```

```
$ http GET https://xxxx/interface/login/
HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Allow: OPTIONS, GET
Cache-Control: max-age=600
Connection: keep-alive
Content-Encoding: gzip
Content-Type: application/json
Date: Mon, 20 Feb 2017 22:46:04 GMT
Expires: Mon, 20 Feb 2017 22:55:56 GMT
Last-Modified: Mon, 20 Feb 2017 22:45:56 GMT
Server: nginx/1.10.2
Strict-Transport-Security: max-age=31536000
Transfer-Encoding: chunked
Vary: Accept-Encoding

{
    "TOKEN": "33c9c41ab0208042750e100f89efb7270c0bda9c588413cb26304499c39b4ead"
}

```

Sending a request with header:

```
$ http GET https://xxxx/interface/request/ "Authorization:Token 249e547d5e585f103c321a67ea4da4e48ed37d154dbbe674741a9864753aa868d"
HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Allow: OPTIONS, GET
Cache-Control: max-age=600
Connection: keep-alive
Content-Encoding: gzip
Content-Type: application/json
Date: Mon, 20 Feb 2017 22:46:19 GMT
Expires: Mon, 20 Feb 2017 22:55:43 GMT
Last-Modified: Mon, 20 Feb 2017 22:45:43 GMT
Server: nginx/1.10.2
Strict-Transport-Security: max-age=31536000
Transfer-Encoding: chunked
Vary: Accept-Encoding

{
<some stuff?
}

```

Sending the same request without header, from a different device, in a different network, with a different remote ip, just gives the same result.

If I delete the token, the result is right:

```
$ http POST https://droag.annorath-game.com/interface/request/HTTP/1.1 401 Unauthorized
Allow: OPTIONS, GET
Connection: keep-alive
Content-Type: application/json
Date: Mon, 20 Feb 2017 22:24:56 GMT
Server: nginx/1.10.2
Transfer-Encoding: chunked
WWW-Authenticate: Token

{
    "detail": "Authentication credentials were not provided."
}
```

What can be the cause of this? I don't get it currently.

items.title: Recommended TOKEN_TTL?
items.body:
Unless I've confused myself, when a token has expired the client will need to login again to obtain a new token.

The default is 10 hours, but that seems very short given Knox could be providing tokens to mobile apps. Is there a reason to keep the TTL low?

It would be really helpful to add any clarification to the documentation!

items.title: OpenSSL issue and possible use of urandom
items.body:
Hi @James1345 and other contributors, first thanks for the great app!

I use Knox in production on several projects. This time I need to deploy one of those in a Linux shared server in a hosting provider (WebFaction). The problem is when I login I always receive the same token no matter the user credentials I send. Naturally, when trying to login a second time I get:

```
"(1062, "Duplicate entry '1080f871e39cc839e5bcc9f852f9a8f3ddc03cf7e72e9fd1d6e4a71d7e74936f' for key 'PRIMARY'")".
```

I noticed the problem is with the random bytes generation. When Knox tries to generate salt and token it only gets a bunch of zeros from `OpenSSL.rand.bytes`. So when it uses the zeros to digest the token, the result is always the same. This generates a database error since token field is, of course, unique.

As I needed to deploy the project fast I started to mess around with Knox code and found that if I replace the `OpenSSL.rand.bytes` with `os.urandom` it solves the problem. Is also good to mention both `os.urandom` and `OpenSSL.rand.bytes` work fine in the Python terminal of the same server.

In the documentation of Knox is said that "DRF Tokens are generated with os.urandom, which is not cryptographically secure. Knox uses OpenSSL to provide tokens." But the documentation of [pyOpenSSL rand](http://www.pyopenssl.org/en/stable/api/rand.html) module says "Functions from this module shouldn’t be used. Use urandom instead." pointing the [this](https://sockpuppet.org/blog/2014/02/25/safely-generate-random-numbers/) article.

So could some one clarify if is it really worse to use `os.random` and why?

items.title: Custom User Models with custom 'username' fields fail during serialization
items.body: When using knox, if I have a custom model that doesn't use `username` as the username field, like say `email_address`, the `UserSerializer` fails because Django lets us have custom username fields. (See: https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/1.10/topics/auth/customizing/#django.contrib.auth.models.CustomUser.USERNAME_FIELD)

items.title: Include cryptography in dependencies and drop PyOpenSSL
items.body: I see that knox uses PyOpenSSL to generate random numbers for the tokens. According to the [cryptography documentation](https://cryptography.io/en/latest/random-numbers/) using `os.urandom` is fine.

items.title: Performance Issue
items.body:
As the readme doesn't really state it: django-rest-knox has a major performance issue.

https://github.com/James1345/django-rest-knox/blob/master/knox/auth.py#L50

This line leads to _major_ performance hits once one reaches significant user numbers, as each API request leads to all tokens being sent do the Django instances. Once reaching a few tens of thousands of users and more than a handful of requests per second, the application is spending more time receiving/parsing SQL and guessing tokens than doing some actual work.

One way to change this would be the following: Split the token in 2 parts:
- Part one is an identifier for a database column,  e.g.  a random string
- Part two is the very token knox currently uses

This would lead to only querying for a single row (the one matching part on), then comparing one hash.

Funfact: While loadtesting I watched my servers handle > 100mbit/s of SQL due to this bug.

items.title: Error when user send token is not valid length
items.body:
When i send token with token(len) is longer or shorter token, the program is exception:


items.title: django-rest-knox always response HTTP 401
items.body:
hello, i am a newbie in django. I want to **django-rest-knox** authentication in my REST API, it's better than simple simple DRF Tokens .

I try to authenticate first created user : 

> curl -X POST -d "email=ejoinel@yahoo.fr&password=bejoilty" http://localhost:8000/api/auth/login/

But i always receive HTTP 401 error
I tried several solutions , but nothing works.
My settings:

![capture d ecran 2016-04-05 a 01 10 50](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8337279/14266893/f3a66034-facb-11e5-86a7-a575bf660c1b.png)

![capture d ecran 2016-04-05 a 01 11 06](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8337279/14266906/065adf0c-facc-11e5-94a2-d7c49c0dd8e9.png)

My user model inherited **AbstractBaseUser**

My model

![capture d ecran 2016-04-05 a 01 09 18](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8337279/14266930/50b932ba-facc-11e5-8bfc-c2ded91a994a.png)

My UserSerializer

![capture d ecran 2016-04-05 a 01 10 06](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8337279/14266938/67d7297a-facc-11e5-88db-dc9d3d021e0b.png)

Can someone tell me where is my mistake, please.

items.title: Why empty body for login?
items.body:
Is there any particular reason of why POST empty body approach for login?

An perhaps a stupid question is: how do you do that? I always get Authentication credentials were not provided.

items.title: unsupported operand type(s) for +: 'datetime.datetime' and 'int'
items.body:
AuthToken.objects.create function tries to add expires as integer to datetime resulting in the above exception.  It should be wrapped as a timedelta instead.

http://james1345.github.io/django-rest-knox/settings/

Here in the doc you do mention that TOKEN_TTL should be timedelta but then the example settings show it to be an integer. Either the doc should be fixed or you should support integer as hours as also mentioned in the doc.

```
  REST_KNOX = {
    'SECURE_HASH_ALGORITHM': 'cryptography.hazmat.primitives.hashes.SHA512',
    'AUTH_TOKEN_CHARACTER_LENGTH': 64,
    'TOKEN_TTL': 10,
    'USER_SERIALIZER': 'knox.serializers.UserSerializer',
 }
```

items.title: Login View Requing Authenticated User
items.body:
I have seen this been discussed in 
https://github.com/James1345/django-rest-knox/issues/7

I would like to share my point of view and an alternative solution here :) :).

The LoginView we have right now requires the user to be authenticated in the first place. This means, first the user has to pass a valid Token (somehow obtained earlier) in the HTTP Authorization Header or have a Valid Session, etc in order to pass permission classes in  https://github.com/James1345/django-rest-knox/blob/master/knox/views.py#L16.

Is this the desired behavior for a Login View or API? Shouldn't we allow users, who are not authenticated yet, to pass credentials, authentic the credentials and finally login the user. So the LoginView will take in credentials like username, password etc, authenticate the credentials, and finally create an AuthToken and return response.

items.title: Why does LoginView use the IsAuthenticated permission class?
items.body: Is there something I'm missing?

items.title: AuthTokenManager super() requires arguments in Python 2
items.body:
this bit triggers a type error: "super() takes at least 1 argument (0 given)"

auth_token = super().create(digest=digest, salt=salt, user=user) 

I am using python 2.7.6 with django 1.8.2. 

I guess this would work as expected in Python 3.

items.title: Python 2.7 compatibility
items.body:
Hi. Great work!

In models.py , maybe change the following line:
        auth_token = super().create(digest=digest, salt=salt, user=user)
to:
        auth_token = super(AuthTokenManager,self).create(digest=digest, salt=salt, user=user)

for Python 2.7 compatibility?

items.title: why not to add ttl for the tokens?
items.body: time to live, will allow to manage time limited sessions - will force to re-login user, with optional session extension will be a full end-to-end authentication

items.title: Add to django packages / rest framework docs
items.body:
Looks good!

Want to consider adding to the rest framework grid on django packages: https://www.djangopackages.com/grids/g/django-rest-framework/

Also PR linking to this from the rest framework 'third party packages' docs in auth section would make sense.

Cheers!
